name: Linux Distribution Feature Groups
description: This parent feature covers the core mandatory packages, ostree support, conflict resolution, graphical environments, design and development tools, and legacy system components required for various Linux distribution products and use cases. It ensures a comprehensive management and development ecosystem for client, server, workstation, and compute node products. This feature group includes support for package groups targeting specific functionalities such as GUI frameworks, software development, and design applications, while addressing conflicts across repositories and installation variants.

name: System Management and Diagnostic Tools
description: A comprehensive collection of tools and utilities for managing, diagnosing, and optimizing Linux systems, providing functionality for system administration, debugging, performance analysis, security auditing, connectivity, and remote management. This feature encompasses both graphical and command-line tools as well as utilities for diverse scenarios including server, desktop, headless, and large-scale systems.

name: Linux Installation and Critical Path Framework
description: This parent feature encompasses all aspects of Linux installation, core system functionality, critical path components, and specialized setups across various use cases and environments. It includes basic and minimal installations, critical applications and shared platform packages, and tailored configurations for different desktop environments, server editions, robotics development, and initial setups. The feature ensures modularity, extensibility, and critical system packages needed for both runtime and build-time operations within diverse Linux distributions.

name: Development and Compatibility Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of tools, libraries, environments, and support systems designed for application development, cross-platform compatibility, and legacy migration. This feature encompasses support for a wide variety of programming languages, development frameworks, web application stacks, and compatibility layers to enable the building, running, and maintaining of modern and legacy applications on Linux systems.

name: Cloud and Virtualization Management Suite
description: A comprehensive set of tools and utilities designed to support, manage, and optimize environments that utilize cloud computing, virtualization, and containerization. This feature suite encompasses bootloader tools for cloud images, cloud management utilities, server tools for cloud environments, and virtualization-specific packages for various platforms. Additionally, it includes tools for container management (such as Docker and Kubernetes), guest agents for hypervisors, virtualization environments (both graphical and headless), and utilities for various hypervisor platforms. The suite also addresses offline management of virtual images and integrates advanced support for virtualized network components like OpenvSwitch. The ultimate goal is to unify the management and execution of virtualized, containerized, and cloud-based workloads under a single umbrella of capabilities, ensuring efficient and reliable operations.

name: Development and Creative Tools
description: A comprehensive collection of tools, libraries, and utilities designed to support software development, creative production, scientific research, and educational purposes. This feature encompasses a diverse range of utilities for programming in multiple languages, document authoring, graphics and audio creation, technical writing, and education. Additionally, it includes essential toolkits and specialized environments for packaging, internationalization, and advanced computational tasks.

name: Infrastructure and Identity Management Services
description: A comprehensive suite of features and tools designed to support, manage, and optimize IT infrastructure, service availability, storage, identity management, and cloud computing. This parent feature encompasses server and client solutions for backing up data, managing directory services, handling cloud and network infrastructure, providing secure identity and certificate management, and ensuring high availability and resilient storage. It also includes essential tools for domain integration, remote desktop connectivity, smart card authentication, and load balancing, catering to both enterprise and cloud-scale implementations.

name: Linux System Feature Groups
description: A comprehensive collection of feature groups designed to cover a variety of functionality in Linux systems. These feature groups include tools, libraries, applications, and utilities tailored for different use cases, such as system administration, development, networking, accessibility, hardware support, scientific computing, database management, graphics manipulation, internet applications, font design, and more. It serves as an umbrella feature to organize and manage various sub-features that enhance and extend the capabilities of Linux-based environments, making them suitable for a wide range of professional, educational, and personal use cases.

name: System Service and Application Stack
description: A comprehensive collection of software features and packages that enable the system to act as a host for various services, applications, and server functionalities. This feature provides support for database management systems, web servers, email and network servers, printing solutions, file storage, web browsers, load balancers, and legacy protocols. Together, these capabilities allow the system to function as a versatile platform for hosting modern and legacy services, facilitating communication, storage, processing, and user interaction across multiple domains.

name: Desktop Environments and Window Management
description: A comprehensive collection of desktop environments, window managers, and supporting applications for graphical user interfaces on Linux. This parent feature encompasses lightweight desktop environments for low-specification systems, feature-rich environments for modern UX needs, tiling window managers, and related applications and packages. It includes options for traditional desktops, innovative user interfaces, and compatibility with legacy X Window System environments.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Desktop Environment and Productivity Features
description: A comprehensive set of features and tools that enhance Linux desktop environments, providing office suites, multimedia support, productivity tools, and additional extensions for various desktop environments such as KDE, Xfce, LXDE, LXQt, and Deepin. Includes educational applications, personal information management tools, media playback, and translation support to create a robust and versatile user experience across different platforms.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel
